In recent years, mobile technologies have been developed and used in education. Some examples of mobile technologies include a personal digital assistant (PDA), smartphone, and e-book. These mobile devices often use context-aware technologies, which adapt to the user's environment, and connect to wireless networks to enhance learning experiences that differ from traditional methods. Previous studies have shown that mobile learning, which is learning facilitated by mobile devices, can significantly improve interaction between students and their learning environments, helping them achieve their educational goals.

In the realm of mobile learning, it has become increasingly important to use mobile devices and appropriate learning methods or strategies to enhance the learning experience for different students. This study aims to examine the learning achievements and attitudes of elementary school students who participated in a campus plant learning activity using mobile devices and competitive learning strategies. The experimental results indicate that the group of students using competitive learning strategies performed better academically than those who did not use these strategies. After completing the learning activity, both groups of students showed a positive attitude toward their learning experiences.
